statement.text: Carotid Endarterectomy (CEA) is a surgical procedure to remove atherosclerotic plaque from the carotid artery, reducing stroke risk in patients with significant carotid stenosis. It is the gold standard treatment for symptomatic stenosis ≥50% and asymptomatic stenosis ≥60-70%, with landmark trials (NASCET, ECST, ACAS) demonstrating stroke reduction.
statement.formal: CEA: Surgical exposure of carotid bifurcation → Arteriotomy → Plaque endarterectomy → Arteriotomy closure (primary or patch) | Indication: Symptomatic ≥50% | Asymptomatic ≥60-70% | Target: Combined stroke/death <3% (asymptomatic) or <6% (symptomatic)

explanation.intuition: CEA is essentially 'cleaning out' a clogged artery. The surgeon makes an incision in the neck, exposes the carotid artery, temporarily stops blood flow, opens the artery, and physically removes the cholesterol plaque like scraping wallpaper off a wall. Then the artery is closed, blood flow restored, and the now-clean artery is less likely to throw off clots to the brain.
explanation.key_insight: The benefit of CEA depends entirely on surgical expertise - it only helps if the combined stroke/death rate is below 3% (asymptomatic) or 6% (symptomatic). If the surgeon's complication rate is higher, the operation causes more strokes than it prevents. This is why outcomes are tracked and volume matters.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: (1) Neck incision along sternocleidomastoid; (2) Exposure of common, internal, and external carotid arteries; (3) Systemic heparinization; (4) Clamping proximal and distal to plaque; (5) Shunting if needed (based on EEG, stump pressure, or surgeon preference); (6) Arteriotomy from CCA into ICA; (7) Plaque dissection and removal; (8) Tacking sutures for distal endpoint; (9) Closure with patch (vein or prosthetic) or primary; (10) Clamp removal and flow restoration. Eversion CEA is an alternative: transecting the ICA, everting and removing plaque, then reanastomosing.
common_misconceptions: CEA is major surgery - it's well-tolerated, often done under regional anesthesia
All carotid stenosis needs CEA - asymptomatic disease benefit is marginal with modern medical therapy
CEA eliminates stroke risk - it reduces but doesn't eliminate risk, especially contralateral/lacunar strokes
Carotid stenting has replaced CEA - CEA remains the standard; stenting for selected patients

definitions_glossary.endarterectomy: Surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from within an artery
definitions_glossary.shunt: Temporary tube allowing continued cerebral blood flow during clamping
definitions_glossary.patch_angioplasty: Widening arteriotomy closure with patch to prevent stenosis
definitions_glossary.eversion_technique: Alternative CEA method everting artery to remove plaque
definitions_glossary.stump_pressure: ICA pressure with CCA clamped, indicates collateral adequacy

symptomatic_stenosis.timing: Within 2 weeks of TIA/stroke is optimal
symptomatic_stenosis.benefit: NNT ~6 for 70-99% stenosis to prevent one stroke over 2 years

asymptomatic_stenosis.benefit: NNT ~17-20 to prevent one stroke over 5 years

contraindications: High surgical risk with minimal symptoms
Severe neurologic deficit (no brain to save)

shunt_use.selective: Based on stump pressure, EEG, or awake monitoring

closure_options.patch: Dacron, PTFE, or vein patch (lower restenosis)

landmark_trials.name: NASCET
landmark_trials.finding: CEA reduces stroke by 65% in symptomatic 70-99% stenosis

landmark_trials.name: ECST
landmark_trials.finding: Confirmed NASCET findings in European population

landmark_trials.name: ACAS
landmark_trials.finding: CEA reduces stroke in asymptomatic ≥60% stenosis if perioperative risk <3%

definition.@value: Surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from carotid artery to prevent stroke

sources.citation: North American Symptomatic Carotid Endarterectomy Trial (NASCET). N Engl J Med. 1991;325:445-453.

learning_objectives: Describe the technique of carotid endarterectomy
List indications for symptomatic and asymptomatic stenosis
Understand the importance of surgical volume and outcomes
Explain the evidence base from landmark trials
clinical_pearls: Symptomatic TIA/stroke should get CEA within 2 weeks for maximum benefit
For asymptomatic stenosis, CEA only helps if perioperative stroke/death <3%
Patch closure reduces restenosis compared to primary closure
CEA is still the gold standard; stenting is for selected high-risk patients

medicalCode.description: Thromboendarterectomy, with or without patch graft, carotid artery
